adjective.description: Attractive in a delicate way without being truly beautiful or handsome.
examples: a pretty little girl with an engaging grin

adverb.description: To a moderately high degree; fairly.
examples: he looked pretty fit for his age

noun.description: An attractive thing, typically a pleasing but unnecessary accessory.
examples: he buys her lots of pretties—bangles and rings and things
she'll be all prettied up and ready to go in an hour

phrases: the case is pretty well over
The paraphrase has it that what we are saying is that the surface is pretty nearly bumpy, or very nearly bumpy, or extremely close to being bumpy.
I'm pretty well convinced a new table will be needed, too, or at least a different one.
The nose aromas are pretty well non-existent, with the merest hint of American oak.
Not that we're expecting any guests in the near future because we're pretty well booked up.
origin: Old English prættig; related to Middle Dutch pertich brisk, clever, obsolete Dutch prettig humorous, sporty, from a West Germanic base meaning trick. The sense development deceitful, cunning, clever, skillful, admirable, pleasing, nice has parallels in adjectives such as canny, fine, nice, etc..
